formatedText.text: You have completed the journey and won the wager!
Put your skills to the test and embark on journey 2 followed by journey 3 and many more adventures with increasing difficulty and exciting new features.
This amazing story started in London on one of the cloudy days in the autumn of 1872.
London, which by this time had a population of five million, stretched along the Thames from the luxurious West End to the industrial East End.

The ancient Westminster Abbey and Tower, St Paul's Cathedral and Buckingham Palace attracted tourists as well as Londoners by no means any less than the recently built Albert Hall, and the Palace of Westminster with the famous Big Ben.
This was a city no less amazing than the story that started in it on that day in October.

Mr. Phileas Fogg lived, at No. 7, Saville Row, Burlington Gardens. He was an enigmatical personage, about whom little was known, except that he was a polished man of the world. He was handsome, well-mannered and undoubtedly rich.
Always calm, with the most dispassionate look on his face, he was a true Englishman.
Phileas Fogg was a member of the Reform, an exclusive club that was housed in an imposing edifice in Pall Mall.
This was the place where on the 2nd of October, 1872 an affair was started that became the subject of many lively discussions in London in the months that followed.
Many of the most honourable members of the Reform, including its chairman Andrew Stuart, gathered in the great saloon of the club that day to discuss the latest London news.
The conversation turned to an article in The Daily Telegraph, stating that it was now possible to travel around the world in 80 days...
All unanimously agreed that it was in fact impossible to make the tour of the world in 80 days. All except Mr. Phileas Fogg...
He had the daring not only to claim that it was possible, but also that he himself was prepared to accomplish the journey.

Mr. Fogg's statement created a lively sensation. Among the most ardent opponents was the chairman of the club Mr. Stuart. When Fogg was prompted to prove his claim by action, the chairman made a wager with him without a moment's hesitation.
The stake was inconceivable: the post of the chairman of the Reform Club. If Mr. Phileas Fogg is able to accomplish the journey around the world in 80 days he will get Mr. Stuart's post.
The adventures begin...

On the very day when this inconceivable wager was made, Phileas Fogg hired a new servant instead of the luckless youth he had dismissed for bringing him shaving water at eighty-four degrees Fahrenheit instead of eighty-six.

The new servant, Jean Passepartout, an honest fellow with a pleasant face and ruddy cheeks, was a true Parisian of Paris, living in London for five years now. At this moment he is alone in Mr. Fogg's house, inspecting it carefully and repeating to himself: "That's good, that'll do".

This is just what I wanted! Ah, we shall get on together, Mr. Fogg and I! What a domestic and regular gentleman! A man who neither travels nor stays from home overnight. This is the kind of master I have been dreaming of my whole life!
Passepartout! Where are you?
I have not been expecting you sooner than midnight and it is only ten to eight.
I know it. We start for Dover in ten minutes. We are going round the world.
Round the world!
In eighty days, so we haven't a moment to lose.
But the trunks?
We'll have no trunks. Put my personal note-book in a carpet-bag. We’ll buy the rest on the way. Make haste!
Certainly, Mr. Fogg!
That's good, that is! And I, who wanted to remain quiet!.. Oh, I do not feel right about this journey… But it is time to prepare the carpet-bag. And where is Mr. Fogg's note-book?
First-class tickets have been purchased; the train leaves in an hour. You have forgotten nothing, Passepartout?
Nothing, monsieur. It is all in this carpet-bag. We can leave for Paris.
There’s one more thing left.
There is nothing I could forget! And your personal note-book is in the carpet-bag.
It concerns my wager. I gave the word of a gentleman that I will bring a unique stamp from every country. Thus it will be possible to judge whether I have accomplished the journey agreed upon.
But any stamp can be purchased in London! Is it worth going at all?
The wager is a matter of honour. There’s still some time left before the train leaves. We need to hurry and get an English stamp!

Leaving London Phileas Fogg could not suspect what a lively sensation his departure would create. The news of the fantastic bet spread through the Reform Club, and afforded an exciting topic of conversation to its members. From the club it soon got into the papers throughout England. Some admired Phileas Fogg, although without much trust in the success of his venture, some openly condemned Andrew Stuart for having accepted a wager which betrayed the mental aberration of its proposer. Concerned with the excessive public attention to himself, the bet and to Phileas Fogg, the Chairman of the Reform Club decides to turn to an old friend of his - detective Fix.
Glad to see you, Mr. Stuart!
Welcome, Fix! Let’s get to business right away. I have called you because I need a man with experience for a delicate favor.
I’d be glad to be of service!

Wonderful! The essence of the matter is as follows: an arrogant and self-confident gentleman has recently made a foolish bet with me. I think, you may have heard -- all of London has been talking about it.
Around the world in eighty days! This venture has made a great deal of noise. Thousands of bets have been made but there aren't many of Fogg's backers left.

All the sensation around the wager is getting on my nerves. It also causes irreparable damage to my reputation. Just like most sensible Englishmen I do not believe in Fogg’s success. Therefore I must not lose. Do you understand me, Fix?
Not quite, Mr. Stuart...
I am asking you to follow Fogg and report on all of his movements.
This is not difficult...

I hope so. I am certain that Fogg will not finish his journey on time, but… if by any chance you will be presented with an opportunity … a possibility to cause a little delay in Mr. Fogg's journey, make it a bit longer...
Not causing any suspicions?
I am glad you understood me, dear Fix!
Your efforts will be generously rewarded. Of course provided there is a result.
I will do everything that is in my power. Be confident, you will win the wager!

In the meantime our respectable gentleman and his servant safely reached the capital of France, Paris. Having just gotten off the train, they are hurrying to the port to embark upon the Magnolia, a steamer departing for Egypt later today. Nothing shall stand in the way of Mr. Phileas Fogg...
Oh, Paris – I have not been to Paris for five years! And this is where I grew up, Mr. Fogg. I would be happy to show you around the places that are so dear to me. We'll call on my auntie and...
Passepartout, the most precious thing in our journey is time! We can not waste any at all. Besides, we've almost reached the port. Ah, and here is the captain of the Magnolia.
Monsieurs, how can I help you?
We would like to reach Egypt on your ship.
I’m afraid this is impossible, monsieur. The ship has been seriously damaged in a storm and needs repair. The soonest we can leave is 2 weeks from now.
But I can’t wait that long! Isn’t there anything that can be done?

The repair of the ship, monsieur, is not an easy task. Besides, many of the parts did not survive and need to be replaced completely. And if you do not mind me asking, why the rush, monsieur? You are in Paris – relax and enjoy your time here.
Yes, Mr. Fogg, this is an excellent occasion to visit my...
Passepartout! We'd better think about how to help get the Magnolia repaired. We must get to Egypt as soon as possible!
Monsieurs, thank you for your help in the repair of the ship! Without your assistance it would have taken us forever to accomplish this serious task.
Now the Magnolia is ready for departure to Egypt, monsieurs. We can set sail immediately.
Well, Mr. Fogg, now we can continue our journey. Goodbye, France! Goodbye, Paris!
Do not say goodbye just yet, Passepartout. We still have one more thing to do before we leave.
Oh, Mr. Fogg, so we will get a chance to take a walk around Paris?
Passepartout, you, I am sure, have forgotten about the proof which we are to bring from every country on our route. Before leaving for Egypt we must get a stamp from Paris.

Phileas Fogg and Passepartout arrived to Egypt. After dinner they set out to look for that special rare stamp right away. However, their plan is not destined to be realized. Very strangely all the souvenir shops, post offices and even bazaars are closed this evening. Why could this be?
It turns out that an impudent robbery has just taken place and the most precious of relics have been stolen from the Egyptian Museum. The news came as a shock.
Detective Fix enters the scene...
Terrible news, my fair colleague! The unique ancient artifacts have been stolen! It is the pride of Egypt! How could this happen?

We have not been able to get any particulars yet. The place was crowded at the time the crime took place. Two ships came in from Europe this evening and most of the passengers rushed to see the exhibition at the Museum
But of course! To be in Egypt and not visit this museum is the same as to be in Paris and not see the Eiffel Tower!
Precisely! We have informed the customs, but the time is slipping away and the robber has not been found.
It seems like I may know the man you are after. Phileas Fogg! An Englishman who decided to travel around the globe in eighty days.
But that is impossible!

Exactly! It is just a cover for the crimes! He is in Egypt now. He arrived from Europe with his servant Passepartout tonight on the Magnolia and he very well may have been among the crowd at the museum! Besides, he's also suspected of crimes by the English police.
Naturally not every eccentric traveller is a criminal. This could simply be a coincidence. But you are right; this needs to be thoroughly investigated.
Passepartout, we need to hurry. Let’s look for the stamp.
Mr. Fogg, when will I ever get a chance to be in Egypt again? Let’s stay here for a day or two! Take a look at these odd constructions! And the beasts with human heads!

Passepartout, this is the pride of Egypt -- the Pyramids -- one of the seven wonders of the world. The Great Sphinx guards the entry to the valley. Alas, we do not have time to look at the sights -- we have a different goal. Let’s hurry!
I beg your pardon, sir. Are you Mr. Phileas Fogg, an Englishman, who arrived on the Magnolia yesterday evening?
Yes, I am. And whom do I have the honour of addressing?
I am a representative of Egyptian authorities. I am afraid I have to detain you on suspicion of a robbery of the Egyptian Museum until all the particulars of the case are clarified.
What nonsense! How am I related to this? I am in a great hurry and must get to India!
All the ports are closed until the relics have been found. Please, follow me.

What else can I do? I am compelled to obey the authorities. And you, Passepartout, will have to help both me and the investigation. Try to find the treasures; otherwise we can consider the wager lost...
By all means! I will find it, Mr. Fogg, or I am not Passepartout the Quick!
And how am I supposed to find these treasures? I will try to find out more and then will get on with the search immediately!

You are free to go, Mr. Fogg! I apologize for the unfortunate inconvenience. Please understand that it was our duty to check everything thoroughly. Egypt could have been left without its most precious national relics!
Yes, if it were not for my servant Passepartout, your mistake could have cost me very dearly indeed!

We are amazed at the wit and dexterity of Passepartout, Mr. Fogg! He has not only been able to establish that a foreigner could not steal these relics, but also found the secret hiding place in the museum where the robber had hidden the treasures!
Have you found the criminal?
We are after one of the curators. He won't get away. It's a matter of minutes now.
Good luck to you! Can I leave the country now?
Yes. The sea port is open. The ship leaves for India tonight.
Where is Passepartout? We have to hurry. We still need to find that rare Egyptian stamp and then go on our way.

Phileas Fogg and his servant Passepartout arrived at Bombay at noon when the unbearable heat descended upon the city. At the railway station they accidentally run into a young Indian woman who is making her way through the crowd all alone. Mr. Fogg is stunned by her beauty. She is dressed richly and exquisitely but looks very concerned and frightened. After a moment's thought Phileas Fogg decides to start a conversation, having understood that she is in need of help.
I am sorry to start a conversation like this but do you happen to need any help?
No!.. Well, yes. As a matter of fact, I do. But do I dare to bother you with my problems?
Your English is outstanding! Are you from England? What are you doing here? You have to tell me your story. I will do all that's in my power to help you!
My name is Aouda. I’m Indian of the Parsee race, direct descendants of the sect of Zoroaster. I am daughter of a wealthy merchant and my family gave me a thoroughly English education.
Yes, you surely have the manners and intelligence of an English lady!

My parents died, and my uncle decided to marry me to the old rajah of Bundelcund. He is now getting the train tickets for us, and I decided to escape. But where do I go? I will be found everywhere, and it will be only worse then.
Do you think it is possible to affect your uncle's decision?
He can only be influenced by the sparkle of jewels.
Well, if that is the case, I will consider it an honour to help you! I will find all the treasures if India to free you from the bondage!
Now you are free and independent, Miss Aouda.
Mr. Fogg, I am so thankful to you! But...
What's the matter? You look like you are not happy about your liberation.
You see, I have no use for the freedom you have given me. I do not have any other relatives or friends who could help me.
Oh, Miss Aouda, please forgive my tactlessness but I would like to offer you to join me and Passepartout in our journey around the world. Would you agree?
That would be my pleasure, Mr. Fogg. This is a great honour for me.

Excellent! Passepartout is waiting for us at the railway station. But I have one more request. Please help me find a souvenir shop where it is possible to buy a beautiful Indian stamp. And then we'll be on our way!

Phileas Fogg, Passepartout and Aouda crossed the Indian peninsula on elephants and trains and safely arrived to Calcutta where they got on a steamer leaving for China. Detective Fix is in fact on the same ship. After what it cost him to find Fogg in India he now kept a close eye upon him. Fix took it upon himself to cause a delay for Fogg in China whatever the means.

The travellers had a surprise waiting for them on the shore. It turned out no one could leave the port because all of China was celebrating the holiday of the Fiery Dragon. Sparkling kites were flying in the sky, fireworks flared up everywhere, and thousands of people with lanterns of dazzling colours were in the streets. It was neither possible nor safe to get through the crowds.

At this moment Phileas Fogg is deep in thought, contemplating how to get out of China. Passepartout and Aouda are watching the celebrations full of excitement, and detective Fix has a grin of satisfaction on his face - destiny itself has given him an unexpected gift.
What a holiday! I could never imagine anything like this! Mr. Fogg, China is the most incredible country in the world!
Passepartout, you say this about every country we visit. And every time you are right in some way. Alas, we don’t have time to be amazed by the uniqueness of China.
What happened, Mr. Fogg? Why are you so anxious?
We find ourselves in a very difficult situation. I can not think of a way to leave China before the end of the holiday.
Let’s join the celebration, Mr. Fogg! Look at the amazing kites and colourful balloons! It's like a fairy tale!
Yes, yes, a fairy tale... kites, beautiful balls... beautiful kites, air balloons... This is an idea! Passepartout, this is a brilliant idea! We will travel to Japan on an air balloon!
On an air balloon?! Are you joking?
Not at all! We need to find a merchant who sells air balloons.
Look, Mr. Fogg, there is a shop with holiday decorations on the left. Let’s ask the owner where we can buy an air balloon.
I would like to buy the biggest air balloon. Could you help me?
Why not help? The best air balloons in this blessed country, I own.
Name your price! We are in a serious hurry.
The opportunity to fly high in the sky as a bird, I do not sell for money.
What do you want then?
Bring me that which wind creates on a day that hot is.
This is a riddle! We need to bring a fan!
That which tirelessly pleases our ear with singing, I expect from you.
Perhaps it is a mechanical nightingale? It's a popular toy in China.
That which from the burning sun saves, bring me.
A Chinese umbrella!
Merchant, say all your riddles at once!

Fire into water turns, day into night turns. The symbol of unity of all things, bring to me... And forget not the old wise dragon that by the sparkle of its scales blinds, and a mysterious vessel that the living power holds...
The riddles are difficult. Have you finished, wise man?
What light on a pitch-dark night gives? What luck on a long journey brings and from misfortunes protects?
The one who will protect the home from uninvited guests, bring me.
The message of our ancestors on a thin papyrus, you must also find.
I have brought you everything you asked for, wise man. Have we found the right answers to your riddles?
You looked and you saw, you listened and you heard. Now the thing that will allow you over the people to fly, above all to be, I can give you.
I thank you, wise man!
Strongly in your hands hold that which happiness brings.
A new riddle! This is luck. Or winning the wager. Or may be?.. Miss Aouda?
Now, I just need to find a stamp and join my fellow-travellers.

With some adventures on the way Phileas Fogg and his companions reached Japan on a hot air balloon. The strength and direction of the wind changed several times and it seemed like nothing good was to come out of the idea of traveling by air. Yet thanks to the wit and perfect self-control of Mr. Fogg they reached their destination.
At this moment Phileas Fogg and Miss Aouda are in a state of concern. They have been waiting for Passepartout in a designated place for several hours now.

In the meantime detective Fix befriended Passepartout and persuaded him to visit one of Japanese temples. Fix's hope was that the ingenuous but very curious Passepartout would make the mistake so typical of Europeans -- enter the temple without first leaving his shoes outside the door. Everything happened the way the artful Fix had planned.

Passepartout will get in prison, and Phileas Fogg, of course, will not leave his servant alone in Japan. He is a gentleman. That means my plan is perfect. Fogg will lose the bet, and I will receive a good sum of money. Let's see if I can find Fogg and tell him the good news.
Where is Passepartout? Where could he go? He is never late.
It means that something must have happened to him. We have to find him. Poor Passepartout!
Did you say Passepartout? Are you talking about a Frenchman from London?
Do you know him? Where is he?
What happened to him?
I am afraid there has been a very unfortunate misunderstanding. I got acquainted with Passepartout by chance and we decided to see the local sights. We went into an ancient temple.
And Passepartout disregarded the Japanese traditions?
I am afraid so! Before I could say anything he went in with his shoes on, by which he profaned the sacred temple according to local tradition. He was immediately detained.
Yes, in Indian pagodas this is a very serious offence for which one can be even arrested.
Where is Passepartout now?
He is awaiting his verdict in the temple.
But he is a European. He does not know the traditions and did not do that intentionally!
Yes, perhaps so, but this can hardly save him from prison.
Prison? Are you sure?
As far as I am aware, a crime such as this is punishable by a sentence of two months in prison.
Poor Passepartout! What can we do?
I’m afraid, I cannot help you. I have some business to attend to.
We must save Passepartout. I cannot leave him alone in Japan, but I cannot wait for two months either.
I am sure you will find a solution, Mr. Fogg!
Let’s go to the temple. We shall try to explain the situation and perhaps make a generous donation to the temple.
Yes, this will definitely help to mitigate the punishment!
Mr. Fogg, I thank you for rescuing me, for not leaving me all alone here! It is terrible to think of what could happen to me!
Be more careful henceforth! Remember our main goal.
Of course, of course! I shall not leave you even for a moment! Ah, what excellent gifts you have presented to the temple!
Passepartout, if you continue to blab like this, I will take the extra expenses out of your pay.
I am silent, Mr. Fogg. But you should know that you will not find a more devoted servant!
You are incorrigible, Passepartout! Let’s hurry. A difficult journey to America awaits us, and we have yet to find the rare Japanese stamp.
I will help you to find the stamp!

Phileas Fogg and his fellow-travellers crossed the width of the United States "from ocean to ocean", as the Americans say. More adventures awaited them along the way: first a great herd of buffaloes formed an obstacle to the passage of the train, then an unreliable suspension-bridge delayed them, and at the very end, the train was attacked by a band of Sioux, and even Aouda had to defend herself with a revolver in her hands. Having overcome all the difficulties the travellers finally reached their destination.

They immediately rushed to the harbour only to find out the terrible news: the Concord, for Liverpool, had started three-quarters of an hour before! That steamer, in leaving, seemed to have carried off Phileas Fogg's last hope.
Mr. Fogg! We were late by just forty-five minutes! I am crushed.
Yes, this is a very vexing incident to take place right before the final leg of our journey. If we do not think of something right this instant, the bet is lost.
We have gotten so close to the final goal!
Let’s not lose heart. There must be a way! We just need to find it.
I will go and ask the sailors if there is any other ship, leaving for Europe.
Mr. Fogg, they say there is one vessel that could help us get to England.
Great, Passepartout! It seems like you are able to find a way out of any difficult situation.
I was warned, however, Mr. Fogg, that the captain is somewhat eccentric. It may be quite difficult to come to terms with him.
No difficulties will stop us, Passepartout. Take me to this captain!
What in thunder d' ye want? Speak it!
We were told that you can help us get to Europe. We need to be there as soon as it is possible. Is your vessel a swift one?
Just enough speed f'ye, Englishman! But I sees there be a woman amongst ye...
Yes, and what of it? Is this indeed a problem?
No pirate let a woman step onboard. This be a bad sign, how in thunder!
Wait, what pirates are you talking about? It is the end of the 19th century now. There are no pirates anymore!
What are you babbling about, Englishman? How d'ye mean there be no more pirates if I be one of them!
Mr. Fogg, this gentleman has gone mad. Let's go away from here, he can be dangerous...
Wait, Passepartout... Good, Mister, can it be that money will convince you? I offer you sixty thousand dollars for transporting us to England and as soon as possible.
Shiver me timbers! I don't need yer money, Englishman! No doubloons convince a true pirate to take a woman aboard. She stays here or ye be not goin nowhere.
What do we do now, Mr. Fogg? We can not leave Aouda here. How can we persuade this insane gentleman?
Yes, Passepartout, such a man needs a special approach. Let's try to use his mad passion for everything pirate to our advantage.
We are leaving for Europe in a couple of hours. I have arranged everything with the captain.
we soon be back home indeed? I will see London!
Undoubtedly so, Passepartout! If only we get the stamp now.
Let's go for the stamp!
December 21, 1872. London. The eightieth day of the journey.
Phileas Fogg, Passepartout, and Aouda have reached the shores of England.
In Liverpool Mr. Fogg immediately proceeded to enquire about an express train to London. The train left 35 minutes before...

Phileas Fogg then ordered a special train. It was necessary to make the journey from Liverpool to London in five hours and a half. This would have been easy, but there were forced delays on the way. Having made the tour of the world, Phileas Fogg arrived to London at ten minutes before nine and was behind-hand five minutes...
He had lost the wager!

That evening many members of the Reform Club gathered in the great saloon long before nine o'clock. At the moment when the clock indicated eighteen minutes to nine Andrew Stuart got up, saying: 'The train from Liverpool has already arrived to London. Phileas Fogg is not here. We can regard the bet as won'. The members of the Club looked at each other. Then there was a moment of silence. A loud cry was heard in the street, followed by applause, hurrahs, and some fierce growls. Phileas Fogg appeared on the threshold.
Here we are in London for almost twenty-four hours... But we were late, and I am ruined.
I am in despair. I have followed you and become an obstacle in your journey.
I blame no one. Such were the circumstances.
My heart is filled with overflowing gratitude to you! But how can I help you?
Madam! Listen to me!
Of course!
When I decided to bring you far away from India, I was rich and counted on putting a portion of my fortune at your disposal. But now I am ruined.
Oh, Mr. Fogg...
Aouda! I love you! Will you agree to become my wife now, when the circumstance are against me?
Misery itself, shared by two sympathetic souls, may be borne with patience. I agree.
Passepartout, it is half past eight now. Notify the Reverend that tomorrow, Monday, the 23d of December, I wish to marry Aouda.
Also take care of the wedding rings.
Good, Mr. Fogg, everything will be done.
My master! I just came back from the church. Marriage is impossible for tomorrow!
What happened? Why so?
Because tomorrow is ... Sunday!
Yes! Yes! You have made a mistake of one day! We arrived twenty-four hours ahead of time... But now there are only ten minutes left!
We are going to the Reform Club right this instant! I must win the wager...
Here I am, Mr. Stuart! Just as I promised I have traveled around the world in eighty days.
This is impossible!
Here is the necessary proof – rare post stamps from every country. I have won the wager!
I have to admit my defeat, Mr. Fogg! I thought this was impossible. But you have proved the contrary. The title of the Chairman is rightfully yours.
Have you won the bet, Mr. Fogg?
Yes, because we moved eastward. This is why we traveled for seventy nine days, not eighty, and came back on Friday, December 20.
And if it was not for my love for you, and the desire to marry you, I would not have been warned in time about my mistake and...
Dear Mr. Fogg...
Dear Aouda...

formatedText.text: Swap adjacent tiles to make matches of three or more.
Drive all the item pieces to the bottom of the game field by getting rid of tiles underneath them.
Once the item piece is freed through the bottom of the game field it will be added to the item outline.
The clock shows how much time you have left to complete the level.
By matching four tiles or more you recharge and upgrade the power-ups that will help you free the way for the item pieces.
To collect these bonuses free them through the bottom of the game field the same way as with item pieces.
Make matches of three or more tiles to open the stamp under the game field.
The level is completed, when the entire stamp is open.
Put your skills to the test and embark on journey 2 followed by journey 3 and many more adventures with increasing difficulty and exciting new features.
The number of hearts on the panel to the left shows extra lives you have remaining.
The more tiles you match in one go, the more energy is added to power-ups.
Do not always rush to use the Hammer power-up immediately. You can upgrade it to a more potent power-up by continuing to match four tiles or more and accumulating the power-up energy.
Use the Hammer and other power-ups wisely. It's most difficult to get the pieces to the bottom when there are only a couple of lines of tiles left under them.
Even though sometimes it makes sense to continue accumulating the power-up energy to get a more potent one, keep in mind that they cannot be carried onto the next level.
Try to score more points. Every 100 000 bring you an extra life.
You can always see the items collected in the country you are presently in. Click on the carpet-bag in the lower right-hand corner of the game field.
Each stamp is proof of your visit to a certain country. You will need a unique stamp from every country on your journey around the world.
The game includes a beautiful animated screensaver to decorate your desktop. As soon as you advance to a new country its scenes become accessible in the screensaver settings.
The Tesla's Hammer power-up does not only help you get rid of inconvenient tiles but also decreases the number of types of tiles in the game field that may be very useful sometimes.
Try to get rid of the locked tiles at the very beginning as it may be much more difficult to do once they drop lower on the field.
Get bonus points for completing a level quickly.
It is usually easier to get rid of frozen tiles at the very beginning.
It is a good idea to utilize the power-ups on the more difficult levels by intentionally working to recharge them as quickly as possible.
Use the Fireball power-up wisely. It can help drive a piece out of long and narrow parts of the game field.
The game does not end even after you complete all the levels. There are new bonuses to collect and adventures to embark on so you are welcome to continue playing.
You get bonus points for longer chains. These are marked with "Superb!", "Marvelous!" and "Outstanding!"
The clock in the Globe tab shows the actual current time in your time-zone.
Try to free the pieces one by one to avoid having several of them at the bottom of the game field at once. That usually makes matching difficult.
Each level represents a day in your journey, hence the changes in the background. Pay attention when evening sets in because that means there isn't much time left to complete the level.
The Eye button located in the center at the top does not only provide an opportunity to enjoy the animated views of the country you are currently in, but also pauses the game.
You can always look at all the stamps and items you collected in the Globe tab. It also contains the country intros for the places you have already visited that can be viewed again.
All scores are saved in the High Scores Table. Your results are recorded during the game and you can always view them in the table that is accessible from the Main Menu.
Use the scroll buttons on the globe to take a more detailed look at the route of your journey.
Keep up the good work and complete the journey around the world in 80 days!
The classic adventure novel Around the World in Eighty Days was written by the famous French writer Jules Verne in 1873.

text.string: This game is based on the classic novel

formatedText.text: Some characters and events have been modified. Notwithstanding the adaptation of the storyline by the game developer, full credit for the original plot idea remains with Jules Verne. Playrix Entertainment expressly acknowledges the moral rights of the author and has no intention to misrepresent Jules Verne's original novel or cause damage to the author's reputation.

This is the day I hired a new servant, a Frenchman by the name Passepartout. The news of the journey around the world came as a shock to him, yet he started packing without a word. This is the manner a servant should be. It appears that this time I may have found the right man. We are not taking much luggage. A proper gentleman travels around the world with a light carpet-bag.

The most important thing that Passepartout packed is my personal note-book. These notes will become documented evidence of my journey. Perhaps one day, many years from now, I will read them to my children.

I had an argument with Mr. Stuart, chairman of the Reform Club, about whether it is possible to travel around the world in 80 days. He got so agitated trying to prove me wrong that bet his post of the chairman!
Quite honestly it seems like Mr. Stuart is not the only one who thinks I am doomed to failure. Well, gentleman, you will soon see who is right...
This wager has already been referred to as fantastic and inconceivable. I wonder what they will say when I win.
My opinion is that there is nothing fantastic about this bet. All there is here is superb calculation and passion that characterize a true Englishman.

Do I feel strongly about the success of this enterprise? By all means! A true Englishman will not start a new venture unless he is at least 50 per cent sure of the favourable outcome. We are departing for Paris today!

Here we are in Paris. We were finally able to get to the port, yet there was no ship we could embark upon to continue to Egypt. We are thus faced with the first impediments in our journey. The steamer Magnolia we were to board here has gotten into a serious storm. The damage it suffered hinders it from being able to depart within the next two weeks! I have made a decision to help with the repair of the ship whatever the costs.
The additional expenditures to replace the damaged parts promise to be quite substantial, yet the game is worth the candle. Passepartout will help me.
I do not like to compliment the servants but it appears that this new one is indeed a stroke of luck. However, time will tell...

According to Passepartout, Paris is the most beautiful city. The Eiffel Tower, the Champs-Elysees, and Passepartout's auntie's house of course -- all these are of great interest by all means. However we cannot devote any time to sight-seeing.
Our goal is to get the Magnolia repaired as soon as possible. We have absolutely no time to spare!
I am positive I will win the bet. The calculation is accurate, I simply could not err.
Sometimes I feel that anxiety is trying to take over me. My reputation and wellbeing are at stake after all.
The repairs of the ship are going well. It should be sea-worthy shortly.
I had a word with the engineer of the Magnolia. A generous reward convinced him that we may be able to gain some time on the way to Egypt.

All done! The vessel has been repaired and is ready to set sail. We start for Egypt in an hour. We must hurry to get a stamp! Before the Magnolia departs I must find myself proof of my stay in this country...

I could not expect such a turn of events! Having just gone off board in Egypt I was immediately detained by the authorities on suspicion of a robbery of the Egyptian Museum. This is indeed ridiculous! Still, I had to comply and await the arrival of further details of the crime. I have a feeling as if all of this was staged to cause a delay in my journey. But who could do that..?

I have been taken to jail and it looks like they are planning to keep me in custody. They say that because of the incident at the museum the port has been closed altogether, therefore the Magnolia will not leave until the relics have been found. My journey is on the brink of failure!

I am struck by the local traditions that are utterly different from the European. No one speaks English here and I am completely unaware of the events outside. What's the current state of the investigation? Am I still the prime suspect? I can only guess and wait.

Time goes by painfully slowly. My solitude is only consoled by this note-book that they allowed me to take into the cell. The carpet-bag remains with Passepartout. He is my only hope now. No one else can get me out of here. I wonder how he is doing?

I finally got a chance to see and talk to Passepartout! He was able to bribe the guard to allow us a short meeting. We did not have much time and Passepartout could not tell me all. He swore he would get me out of here. He said he is very close to solving this robbery and he only lacks some evidence.

Passepartout saved the day! He is quite some quick fellow I must note. He got me out of jail, helped solve the crime and collect the relics. Now the port is open and the Magnolia can depart for India. It is time to hurry. The journey continues!

Destiny has presented me with an unexpected gift. We ran into a charming yet very sad young lady at the railway station. Her name is Aouda and she told us her story. It turns out that her uncle wants to marry her to a rich and old rajah against her will. She is terrified but no one asks about the bride's consent in India. I must help her!

Everybody knows that India is a great reversed triangle of land, with its base in the north and its apex in the south. The British Crown exercises a real and despotic dominion over the larger portion of this vast country. Yet there are certain ferocious rajahs in the interior who are absolutely independent and uphold the old and often very cruel traditions.

My attention is constantly drawn to Aouda. She is Indian but has the manners of a true English aristocrat, speaks the language with great purity and is absolutely charming. It was worth getting into the risky wager just for the chance to meet her here.

The greed and thirst for gold of Aouda's uncle is quite astonishing. He is prepared to abandon his intention to marry his niece but needs 'weighty arguments' as he put it. Aouda confirmed my suspicions on what that meant -- a generous offering. That is disgusting!

I will note that the Indian Ocean has been favourable, the wind being in the north-west, and all sails aiding the engine. The trip was accomplished most successfully and ahead of time resulting in a gain. I am sure this will be very useful!

Thus, we have been able to convince the uncle to cancel Aouda's wedding. It was not easy. Jewelry and expensive gifts turned out more convincing than any words. We are happy to have Aouda with us in this wonderful journey.

A new blow came in China. All of the country is celebrating the Festival of the Fiery Dragon and it is absolutely impossible to get through the crowd. Until the festival is over we will not be able to leave the country… The idea came quite unexpectedly -- we will travel to Japan on a hot air balloon! However this may not be as easy to accomplish as it seemed at first.

We found a merchant with a stock of balloons but were not able to purchase anything. The old man is not interested in money but is willing to give us a balloon if we crack his riddles. It sounds incredible but nonetheless it is indeed so. We will have to solve his riddles or our brilliant plan on leaving this country is not to be realized.

The journey from India to China is one I shall remember for a long time. I will take note of one thing here: the construction of the railway line that was announced to be completed was in fact not, therefore we had to secure a means of conveyance which came at a rather serious price. Aouda endured the cumbersome journey very well!

In the meantime the big Festival of the Fiery Dragon here continues and there is no end in sight. Passepartout and Aouda are enraptured by the scale and brilliance of the celebration. The air is filled with kites and fireworks. Thousands of people are in the streets with colorful lanterns. Alas, I do not have time for this. I have to solve these mysterious riddles.

The Celestial Empire is extraordinary! I did not pay a pound for the balloon but I did have to spend some time puzzling over the old man's riddles. I just have to put one down for the record. What light on a pitch-dark night gives? What luck on a long journey brings and from misfortunes protects?

Thus, we reached the shores of Japan on a hot air balloon and made it safely to Yokohama where new impediments have been in store for us. This time around Passepartout went into a sacred temple with his shoes on. It is unbelievable but the punishment for a crime like that is two months of imprisonment. We shall undertake to make a generous offering to the temple to try to free him.

It is a matter of honour for me to free Passeparout, for I cannot leave him here entirely alone. I shall never forget how he liberated me from detention in Egypt when I was falsely accused of the museum robbery.
We are presently in Yokohama. Having reached Japan by air we made the journey to this major seaport by land. This is where we will depart for America from.
Yokohama is a principal Japanese port on the Pacific Ocean which takes both cargo and passenger vessels. It is very busy around the clock.

Japan strikes me with the constant whirl of people in the streets. Among the coaches, palanquins and rickshas women mince along in kimonos, the latter being a type of national Japanese costume somewhat similar to a housecoat girded with a wide silk scarf.

I remember my servant Passepartout first looking with great curiosity at everything in the Land of the Rising Sun. It looked as if he was finally beginning to like this journey. Alas, his curiosity cost him dearly. I should not have left him alone...

Our offering for the temple priests is almost ready. I hope it will help to mitigate the punishment and perhaps even free Passepartout. Getting all the gifts was not an easy task -- the culture of this country remains a mystery to me. I thanked Aouda for her help. Her knowledge of the Japanese traditions was instrumental in the choice of gifts to offer.

At last Passepartout is free! It is essential to know the customs and traditions of a country one is traveling to. It is an unwritten law that Passepartout unintentionally broke. The result of that was a delay in time and additional several hundred pounds that it cost us.

We were late to get on the Concord, for Liverpool, by just three-quarters of an hour! There is only one ship in harbor that would be able to transport us to Europe but the captain thereof turned out to be a very strange gentleman indeed. It seems impossible to convince him to take us aboard his ship.

The captain is a very interesting character whose passion is indeed quite astonishing. He is obsessed with pirates! It's unbelievable but just like the old man in China, the captain is not interested in money at all. It looks like we will have to find a way to win his trust somehow.

My fellow-travellers are in a state of despair. We crossed America from the Pacific to the Atlantic to only lose the boat by three-quarters of an hour. It is overwhelming at this point, when we are so close to the final destination!

A separate book of its own could be written about the adventures we encountered on the way. As a matter of fact I expected certain possible obstacles because the "great trunk line" which crosses the entire width of the United States goes through a territory which is still infested by Indians and wild beasts, and a large tract which the Mormons, after they were driven from Illinois in 1845, began to colonise.

The expectations were, alas, legitimate. First a great herd of buffaloes formed an insurmountable obstacle to the passage of the train, then a suspension-bridge thrown over some rapids turned out to be in a ruinous condition. I am again amazed at Aouda's courage!

Scarcely had the train passed the river, when the bridge, completely ruined, fell with a crash into the rapids… Then the train was attacked by a band of Sioux. Aouda behaved courageously from the first. She defended herself like a true heroine with a revolver, which she shot through the broken windows. The remainder of the journey to Omaha we were forced to undertake on a sledge...

Thus, I have been able to win the captain's favor by means of exploitation of his wild passion for everything pirate. He is prepared to help us reach Europe. We are ready to set sail for Britain now and there is still hope that the wager can be won if we can get to Liverpool on time!
